recipes.name: Whole Wheat Flour Ladoos (Atta Ladoo)
ingredients: ⅓ cup + 1 to 2 tablespoons (60g) powdered sugar (organic unrefined cane sugar preferred)
⅓ cup (65g) ghee (clarified butter), at room temperature
directions: Step 1: Grind ⅓ cup of sugar into a fine powder using a dry grinder or small blender. Set aside.
Step 2: In a kadai or thick-bottomed pan, roast 1 cup of whole wheat flour over low heat. Stir frequently for even browning, 7-10 minutes, or until fragrant and lightly colored.
Step 3: Add ⅓ cup of ghee to the roasted flour. Mix well and continue roasting for another 3-5 minutes, stirring constantly, until the flour tastes cooked and no longer raw.
Step 4: Remove the pan from heat. Add the powdered sugar and raisins. Mix thoroughly until well combined and no sugar lumps remain.
Step 5: Once the mixture is cool enough to handle, shape it into medium-sized ladoos using a spoon or your hands. If the mixture is too dry to form ladoos, add a few teaspoons of ghee and mix again.
Step 6: Store the ladoos in an airtight container. They will last for a month in cool weather. Refrigerate in warmer climates.

Use warm, directional light to highlight the golden-brown texture and the glisten of ghee. A shallow depth of field focuses on the front ladoo, with soft bokeh in the background. Incorporate a small brass bowl of raisins and a linen napkin for a touch of rustic elegance.  Shoot from a slightly elevated angle to showcase the round shape and crumbly texture. recipes.name: Peanut Ladoos
ingredients: ⅔ cup jaggery, powdered or grated
directions: Step 1: Heat a thick-bottomed pan over low to medium heat. Add the raw peanuts.

Step 2: Roast the peanuts, stirring frequently, until they are crunchy and fully cooked. Ensure there's no rawness remaining. Test by cooling a few peanuts and tasting them; they should not be hard or raw. Roasting in an oven is also an option.
Step 3: Once roasted, remove the pan from heat and let the peanuts cool to room temperature.
Step 4: Rub the cooled peanuts between your palms to remove their skins.
Step 5: Add the peeled peanuts to a grinder or food processor.
Step 6: Add the powdered or grated jaggery to the grinder.

Step 7: Pulse the grinder in short bursts, checking the texture frequently. Grind until the peanuts reach a coarse consistency, releasing some oil but not turning into peanut butter. The mixture should hold its shape when pressed.
Step 8: Transfer the mixture to a plate or tray.
Step 9: Take small portions of the mixture and shape them into ladoos using your palms.
Step 10: Store the ladoos in an airtight container. Refrigerate if you live in a warm or humid climate; otherwise, store at room temperature.

recipes.name: Badam Ladoo (Almond Balls)
ingredients: ⅔ cup jaggery powder or grated jaggery (60g)
directions: Step 1: Roast the almonds: In a thick-bottomed pan over medium-low heat, roast the almonds, stirring frequently, until fragrant and crunchy. Be careful not to burn them. Alternatively, roast in an oven.
Step 2: Add raisins (optional): Once the almonds are roasted, add the raisins and stir for a minute. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.

Step 3: Grind the mixture: In a mixer or grinder, combine the roasted almonds, raisins (if used), and cardamom seeds. Add the jaggery powder and pulse until a fine mixture forms, releasing some oil and holding its shape when pressed. Do not over-grind.
Step 4: Shape into ladoos: Take small portions of the mixture and roll them into balls.
Step 5: Store: Store the ladoos in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

recipes.name: Coconut Ladoos
ingredients: 1 ½ cups fresh grated coconut, tightly packed
½ teaspoon cardamom powder or 4-5 green cardamom pods, crushed
¾ cup (220 grams) sweetened condensed milk (about ½ of a standard tin)
⅓ cup desiccated or fresh coconut, for rolling
Optional: chopped dry fruits of your choice
directions: Step 1: Heat the ghee in a frying pan or kadai over low heat.
Step 2: Add the tightly packed fresh grated coconut.

Step 3: Stir and roast the coconut over low heat for 3-4 minutes, or until slightly dry. Do not brown the coconut. If using desiccated coconut, skip this step and proceed directly to mixing it with the condensed milk.
Step 4: Add the sweetened condensed milk and cardamom powder to the pan.
Step 5: Stir well and cook the mixture over low heat. Stir regularly, especially as the mixture thickens.
Step 6: Continue cooking until the mixture starts to pull away from the sides of the pan and you see coconut fat separating along the edges. Remove from heat.
Step 7: Transfer the ladoo mixture to a separate bowl or pan and let it cool completely.
Step 8: Once cooled, pinch small to medium-sized portions of the mixture and shape them into balls.
Step 9: Roll each ladoo in the desiccated or fresh coconut until evenly coated.
Step 10: Place the ladoos in small muffin liners or on a tray.
Step 11: Serve immediately or refrigerate for later. These ladoos can be stored in the refrigerator for up to a week.

recipes.name: Ragi Ladoos
directions: Step 1: In a thick-bottomed pan or kadai, dry roast the ragi flour over low heat for 6-8 minutes, stirring constantly until fragrant and lightly colored.
Step 2: Add the ghee to the roasted ragi flour and continue to roast for another 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly, until the flour is crunchy and has no raw taste.
Step 3: Remove the pan from the heat and add the crushed cardamom and powdered jaggery. Mix well.
Step 4: Let the mixture cool slightly until warm enough to handle.  Mix thoroughly again using your hands, breaking up any lumps of jaggery.
Step 5: Once the mixture is cool enough to handle, shape it into small ladoos. If the mixture is too dry to hold shape, add a few tablespoons of room-temperature ghee and mix well before shaping.
Step 6: Store the ragi ladoos in an airtight container.

recipes.name: Sesame Seed Ladoos
ingredients: 145 grams (1 cup) unhulled white sesame seeds
directions: Step 1: Sort and clean the sesame seeds by removing any small stones or debris.

Step 2: Heat a thick-bottomed pan over low to medium heat. Add the sesame seeds and roast, stirring frequently, until they become fragrant, crunchy, and start to pop (about 4-5 minutes). Transfer to a plate or tray to cool.

Step 3: In the same pan, roast the peanuts over low to medium heat, stirring occasionally, until crunchy and fully cooked. Ensure there is no rawness remaining. Transfer to the plate with the sesame seeds to cool.
Step 4: Turn off the heat. Add the desiccated coconut to the warm pan and roast, stirring constantly, until lightly golden. Transfer to the plate with the sesame seeds and peanuts.
Step 5: Once the roasted ingredients are cool or slightly warm, add them to a grinder jar.
Step 6: Add the jaggery powder and cardamom powder to the grinder.
Step 7: Pulse the grinder in short bursts, scraping down the sides as needed, until the mixture releases some oil and holds its shape when pressed. Avoid over-grinding.
Step 8: Transfer the mixture to a plate or tray.
Step 9: Take small portions of the mixture and shape them into ladoos using your palms.
Step 10: Store the ladoos in an airtight container at room temperature in a cool, dry climate, or in the refrigerator if you live in a warm or humid climate.

recipes.name: Moong Dal Ladoos
ingredients: 1 cup husked and split moong dal (yellow lentils)
¾ cup organic unrefined cane sugar
directions: Step 1: Heat a thick-bottomed pan or kadai over low heat. Add the moong dal. (Optional: Rinse and dry the moong dal before roasting.)
Step 2: Roast the moong dal, stirring frequently, until golden brown and aromatic. Ensure even cooking and browning by using a heavy-bottomed pan.
Step 3: Remove the roasted dal from the pan and let it cool.
Step 4: Once cooled, grind the roasted moong dal into a fine powder using a grinder.
Step 5: Sift the moong dal flour into a plate, tray, or bowl. Set aside.
Step 6: In the same grinder, grind the sugar and cardamom seeds (removed from the pods) into a fine powder.
Step 7: Combine the powdered sugar and cardamom with the sifted moong dal flour. Mix well.
Step 8: Melt the ghee in a pan over low heat. Do not overheat.
Step 9: Add the melted ghee to the moong dal-sugar mixture and mix thoroughly with a spatula or spoon.
Step 10: Let the mixture cool slightly, then mix again with your hands.
Step 11: Shape the mixture into small ladoos. If the mixture is too warm to handle, let it cool further.
Step 12: Store the ladoos in an airtight container at room temperature or refrigerate.

recipes.name: Besan Ladoo (Gram Flour Sweet Balls)
ingredients: ½ cup (125 grams) Ghee (clarified butter), plus more as needed
1 cup (175 grams) Powdered sugar (heaped) or Boora or Castor sugar or Confectioner's sugar (alternatively, powder ¾ cup white sugar or raw sugar)
1 teaspoon Cardamom powder (or 5-6 Green cardamoms, powdered)
directions: Step 1: Dry roast the besan in a heavy kadai or pan over low to medium-low heat for 10-12 minutes, stirring continuously to prevent burning and ensure even cooking.

Step 2: Add the ghee and mix well. Continue roasting for another 12-15 minutes, stirring constantly. The mixture will release ghee, develop a nutty aroma, and achieve a molten lava-like consistency. It will also pull away from the sides of the pan.
Step 3: Remove the pan from the heat and add the powdered sugar. Mix vigorously until the sugar melts and no lumps remain.
Step 4: Add the cardamom powder, raisins, and cashews. Mix well.
Step 5: Let the mixture cool to lukewarm or room temperature.
Step 6: Once cooled, shape the mixture into small or medium-sized ladoos. If the mixture is too soft, freeze for 5 minutes or refrigerate for 20 minutes before shaping.
Step 7: Store the ladoos in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a month or refrigerate (note that refrigeration may harden the ghee).

recipes.name: Sattu Ladoos
ingredients: ½ cup Jaggery powder or grated jaggery
directions: Step 1: Heat 1 tablespoon of ghee in a kadai or pan over low heat.
Step 2: Add the sattu flour and roast for 2 minutes, stirring continuously, until lightly roasted. Transfer to a separate bowl.
Step 3: In the bowl with the roasted sattu flour, add the jaggery powder (or grated jaggery) and cardamom powder.
Step 4: Mix the ingredients thoroughly.
Step 5: Add 2 tablespoons of ghee to the mixture and mix well until combined. If the mixture is too coarse due to jaggery granules, briefly pulse it in a mixer-grinder until smooth.
Step 6: While the mixture is still warm, shape it into ladoos. If the mixture is too dry to form ladoos, add a few teaspoons of ghee until the desired consistency is achieved.
Step 7: Serve the sattu ladoos as a sweet snack. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week, or refrigerate in hot and humid climates.

recipes.name: Indian Sweet Rava (Semolina) Ladoos
ingredients: 1/3 cup shelled, unsalted raw pistachios, roughly chopped
1 teaspoon cardamom powder or coarsely ground cardamom seeds
1/2 cup fine granulated white sugar or powdered sugar
1/2 cup unsweetened grated dried coconut or fresh grated coconut
1/3 cup room temperature or lukewarm milk
directions: Step 1: Roughly chop the pistachios. If desired, chop the raisins as well.
Step 2: If using cardamom seeds, coarsely grind them in a mortar and pestle.
Step 3: In a non-stick or heavy-bottomed pan, melt the ghee over medium heat.
Step 4: Add the raisins and pistachios to the melted ghee and sauté for 2-3 minutes, until the raisins swell and the pistachios begin to change color. Be careful not to burn the raisins.
Step 5: Add the grated coconut and cook for another 1-2 minutes, toasting lightly. Avoid burning the coconut, as it can impart a bitter taste.
Step 6: Gradually add the milk while stirring continuously with a spatula to prevent lumps. The semolina will absorb the liquid quickly.
Step 7: Continue cooking for one more minute, then remove the pan from the heat.
Step 8: Allow the mixture to cool slightly, about 5-7 minutes, until it is easy to handle but still pliable.
Step 9: Grease your hands and take approximately 2 tablespoons of the mixture. Roll it tightly into a small, lemon-sized ladoo.
Step 10: Repeat with the remaining mixture. Do not let the mixture cool completely, or it will be difficult to form ladoos.
Step 11: Serve warm with hot chai for breakfast or as a sweet treat after a meal.

recipes.name: Boondi Ladoo
ingredients: 1/2 to 3/4 cup Water (adjust to get a flowing batter)
directions: Step 1: In a pan, dry roast cashews until lightly browned. Add raisins and fry until golden. Remove from pan and set aside. Powder cloves and cardamom using a mortar and pestle. Set aside.
Step 2: Sieve besan flour with baking soda into a mixing bowl. Gradually add water to form a thick paste, then more water until a flowing batter is achieved. Add yellow food coloring.

Step 3: Heat oil for deep frying.  Use two ladles: one for pouring the batter and one with holes for frying the boondi. To test batter consistency, dip the back of a spoon into the batter and hold it over the hot oil. If it drops as round balls, the batter is ready.

Step 4: Pour a ladle of batter over the perforated ladle, holding it above the hot oil. The batter will drip through the holes, forming boondi.  Alternatively, spread the batter in a circular motion over the ladle. Turn boondi over to cook evenly. They should be cooked but not crispy.
Step 5: Remove boondi from oil and drain on a paper towel-lined plate. Wipe the boondi ladle clean between batches.

Step 6: In a wide vessel, combine sugar and water, heating until the sugar dissolves. Check for single-thread consistency: a drop of syrup between your thumb and index finger should form a thin thread. Set aside.
Step 7: Add the drained boondi to the warm sugar syrup.  Mix in the fried cashews, raisins, edible camphor, powdered cardamom, cloves, and sugar candy.
Step 8: While the mixture is still warm, grease your hands and shape the boondi mixture into ladoos, pressing firmly.

recipes.name: Indian Sweet Semolina Ladoos
ingredients: 3/4 cup fine semolina flour (sooji or rava)
1/3 cup shelled, unsalted raw pistachios, roughly chopped
1 teaspoon cardamom powder or coarsely ground cardamom seeds
1/2 cup fine granulated white sugar or powdered sugar
1/2 cup unsweetened grated dried coconut (or fresh grated coconut)
1/3 cup room temperature or lukewarm milk
directions: Step 1: Roughly chop the pistachios. If desired, chop the raisins as well.
Step 2: If using cardamom seeds, coarsely grind them in a mortar and pestle. Alternatively, use cardamom powder.

Step 3: In a non-stick or heavy-bottomed pan, melt the ghee over medium heat. Add the raisins and pistachios and sauté for 2-3 minutes, until the raisins swell and the pistachios begin to change color. Be careful not to burn the raisins.
Step 4: Add the grated coconut and cook for 1-2 minutes, toasting lightly. Be careful not to burn the coconut, as it can add a bitter taste.
Step 5: Add the semolina flour to the pan and roast for 3-4 minutes, stirring constantly, until it turns light golden brown and fragrant.
Step 6: Add the sugar and cardamom and mix well.

Step 7: Gradually add the milk while stirring continuously to prevent lumps. The semolina should come together and form a cohesive mixture. Cook for another minute, then remove from heat. The mixture should be moist but not runny. Adjust the milk quantity as needed.

Step 8: Let the mixture cool slightly for 5-7 minutes, until it's easy to handle. Grease your hands and take about 2 tablespoons of the mixture. Roll it tightly into a small lemon-sized ladoo. Repeat with the remaining mixture.
Step 9: Serve the ladoos warm with hot chai for breakfast or as a sweet treat after a meal.

recipes.name: Atta Ladoo (Whole Wheat Flour Sweet Balls)
directions: Step 1: Sift the whole wheat flour through a fine-mesh sieve into a dry skillet. Dry roast the flour over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the color slightly changes and a light aroma develops. Be careful not to burn the flour. Transfer the roasted flour to a bowl and set aside to cool.
Step 2: In a dry grinder or food processor, grind the granulated sugar into a fine powder. Set aside.
Step 3: Grind the cashews, almonds, and pistachios together to a coarse mixture. Set aside.
Step 4: In a large mixing bowl, combine the cooled roasted wheat flour, powdered sugar, and cardamom powder. Whisk well to combine.

Step 5: Gently heat the ghee for about a minute until it melts completely. Gradually add the warm melted ghee to the dry ingredients, mixing continuously with a ladle or spatula until the mixture comes together.
Step 6: Once the mixture is cool enough to handle, shape it into small, round ladoos using your hands.

scenes.voice_over: In a bowl, combine the cooled roasted flour, powdered sugar, and cardamom powder. Mix them well.

scenes.voice_over: Melt the ghee and gradually pour it into the dry ingredients while mixing constantly. Ensure the mixture combines thoroughly.

recipes.name: Besan Ladoo (Gram Flour Sweet Balls)
directions: Step 1: Sift the besan flour into a bowl and set aside. In a small pan, heat 1 teaspoon of ghee. Add the broken cashews and roast until golden brown. Set the roasted cashews aside.

Step 2: Heat the remaining 1/4 cup of ghee in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Add the sifted besan flour and roast, stirring continuously, until golden brown (about 7-10 minutes). Be sure to keep stirring to prevent burning.
Step 3: Add the cardamom powder and saffron to the roasted besan flour. Mix well and remove from heat.
Step 4: Let the roasted besan mixture cool slightly for about 5 minutes. Then, add the powdered sugar and mix until thoroughly combined.
Step 5: Transfer the mixture to a mixing bowl. Add the roasted cashews and remaining 3 tablespoons of melted ghee. Mix well until a smooth dough forms.

Step 6: While the mixture is still slightly warm, grease your hands with a little ghee to prevent sticking. Shape the dough into small balls (ladoo). This recipe should yield approximately 8 lemon-sized ladoos.

recipes.name: Coconut Ladoos
directions: Step 1: In a pan over medium heat, combine the desiccated coconut and ground cardamom. Mix well and heat for 1 minute, ensuring the coconut doesn't brown.
Step 2: Add the orange food coloring (if using).
Step 3: Pour in the sweetened condensed milk. Cook and stir constantly until the coconut mixture begins to stick together, approximately 5 to 8 minutes.
Step 4: Add the rose water (if using) and continue to cook and stir until the flavors meld, about 8 to 10 minutes more.
Step 5: Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture cool slightly until it's safe to handle, but still warm.
Step 6: Roll the coconut mixture into small balls (ladoos).
Step 7: Place the ladoos in cupcake liners or on a baking sheet.
Step 8: Serve immediately or refrigerate for up to a week.

recipes.name: Roasted Gram Flour Ladoo (Maa Ladoo)
directions: Step 1: Dry roast the roasted gram (pottukadalai) in a pan over medium heat for about 3 minutes, or until fragrant. Be careful not to let it change color. Once roasted, transfer to a dry mixer and grind to a fine powder.
Step 2: Grind the sugar to a fine powder in the same dry mixer. Sift the roasted gram flour and powdered sugar together for even mixing.
Step 3: In a pan, heat 1 teaspoon of ghee and fry the broken cashews until golden brown. Set aside.
Step 4: In a mixing bowl, combine the sifted roasted gram flour and sugar mixture, fried cashews, and elachi powder.
Step 5: Heat the remaining ghee in a pan for about a minute until melted. Pour the melted ghee into the mixing bowl with the dry ingredients.
Step 6: Mix well with a ladle or spatula until the ghee is evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
Step 7: Once the mixture is warm enough to handle comfortably, start shaping it into small, round ladoos. Repeat this process until all of the mixture has been used.

recipes.name: Indian Carrot Halwa Ladoos
ingredients: 1 cup shredded Coconut (1/4 cup for halwa, remainder for coating)
directions: Step 1: Wash, peel, and grate the carrots.
Step 2: In a saucepan, melt the butter over medium heat.
Step 3: Add the fennel and cardamom powder to the melted butter and sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Step 4: Add the grated carrots and sauté for 5 minutes, until slightly softened and any released water has evaporated.
Step 5: Add the sugar and milk, and cook over medium-high heat for 8-10 minutes, until the milk has been almost completely absorbed and the carrots are soft but not mushy.
Step 6: Stir in 1/4 cup of the shredded coconut and the sweetened condensed milk. Cook for 3 minutes, or until the condensed milk has almost dried.
Step 7: Mix in the dried cranberries or raisins. Remove from heat and let the mixture cool slightly, about 5 minutes, until it's easy to handle.
Step 8: Spread the remaining shredded coconut on a wide plate.
Step 9: Grease your hands and roll the carrot mixture into 16 equal-sized balls.
Step 10: Roll each ball in the shredded coconut to coat evenly. Place the coated ladoos on a lightly greased plate.
Step 11: For a firmer texture, refrigerate the ladoos in a covered container for 15-20 minutes before serving. Store in the refrigerator if not consuming immediately.

recipes.name: Gajar Halwa Ladoos
directions: Step 1: Wash, peel, and grate the carrots. Melt the butter in a heavy-bottomed non-stick pan over medium-low heat.
Step 2: Add the grated carrots and cardamom powder to the pan. Sauté until the carrots are softened.
Step 3: Add the sugar and milk to the pan. Cook for 10 minutes.

Step 4: Stir in 1/4 cup of shredded coconut, the sweetened condensed milk, and mix well. Continue cooking until the condensed milk has almost dried out. The mixture should be thick enough to roll into balls.
Step 5: Add the dried cranberries or raisins and mix well. Let the mixture rest for about 5 minutes.
Step 6: Spread the remaining 1/2 cup of shredded coconut on a plate. Roll the carrot halwa mixture into small balls.
Step 7: Coat the ladoos evenly with the shredded coconut.
Step 8: Refrigerate the ladoos for 15 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Carrot Coconut Truffles (Ladoo)
ingredients: 1 tbsp unsalted butter, ghee, or oil (for vegan option)
1 cup desiccated coconut, divided (½ cup for mixture, ½ cup for rolling)
directions: Step 1: Wash, peel, and grate the carrots.
Step 2: In a wide pan, melt the butter, ghee, or oil. Toast the sliced almonds until golden brown. Remove the almonds from the pan and set aside.
Step 3: Add the grated carrots to the same pan and sauté over medium heat for 5 minutes, or until slightly softened and any released moisture has evaporated.
Step 4: Add ½ cup of the desiccated coconut to the pan and toast for 1 minute.
Step 5: Pour in the sweetened condensed milk and rose water (if using). Mix well and cook over low heat.
Step 6: Continue cooking for 5-8 minutes, or until the mixture thickens and begins to form a ball.
Step 7: Stir in the toasted almonds. Let the mixture cool slightly, until it's easy to handle.
Step 8: Lightly grease your hands with ghee or oil. Take small portions of the mixture and roll them into round balls.
Step 9: Roll the truffles in the remaining ½ cup of desiccated coconut.
Step 10: Serve immediately or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.

recipes.name: Rava Ladoo (Sooji Ladoo): Indian Semolina Sweet Balls
directions: Step 1: Roast the Semolina: In a steel pan (avoid nonstick), heat 3 tablespoons of ghee or butter. Add the semolina and roast over low heat until fragrant and light brown. Be careful not to burn it.
Step 2: Prepare the Sugar: Finely grind 1 cup of sugar in a dry grinder and set aside.
Step 3: Reduce the Milk: In a separate pan, boil the milk until it reduces to about 200ml.
Step 4: Roast Nuts and Spices: Heat 3 teaspoons of ghee in a nonstick pan. Roast the cashew nuts, raisins, and split cardamom pods until the raisins puff up.
Step 5: Combine Ingredients: Transfer the roasted semolina and powdered sugar to a large bowl. Add the roasted nuts, raisins, and cardamom.

Step 6: Test Mixture Consistency: Take a small portion of the mixture and add a little warm milk. Mix well and see if it holds its shape when rolled into a ball. If it's too dry, add more warm milk gradually.

Step 7: Make Ladoo Balls: If the mixture is the right consistency, roll it into medium-sized balls. If you added milk to the entire mixture, return it to the pan and cook over low heat for 2 minutes before rolling.
Step 8: Coat with Sugar: Roll the ladoos in coarse sugar or sugar sprinkles.

recipes.name: Urad Dal Laddus
ingredients: 230 grams (1 cup) split black lentils (urad dal)
70 grams (⅓ cup) sugar (organic unrefined cane sugar preferred)
80 grams (⅓ cup) ghee (clarified butter), at room temperature
directions: Step 1: Heat a thick-bottomed pan or kadai over low heat. Add the urad dal. (Optional: Rinse and dry the urad dal before roasting.)
Step 2: Roast the urad dal over low heat, stirring frequently, until golden brown and aromatic. This is crucial to prevent stomach upset.
Step 3: Once golden brown, remove the dal from the heat and let it cool completely.
Step 4: In a grinder, grind the cooled urad dal along with the seeds from the cardamom pods into a fine powder.
Step 5: Sift the urad dal flour into a plate, tray, or large bowl.
Step 6: In the same grinder, grind the sugar into a fine powder. (Optional: Sift the sugar as well.)
Step 7: Add the powdered sugar to the sifted urad dal flour and mix thoroughly.
Step 8: Melt the ghee in a pan over low heat. Do not overheat.
Step 9: (Optional) Add chopped dry fruits to the melted ghee and sauté until lightly golden.
Step 10: Pour the melted ghee (and sautéed dry fruits, if using) into the urad dal-sugar mixture.
Step 11: Mix well with a spatula or spoon until combined. The mixture will be slightly fluid.
Step 12: Let the mixture cool to room temperature until the ghee solidifies and the mixture becomes dense enough to shape.
Step 13: Shape the mixture into small to medium-sized ladoos. The warmth of your hands will help soften the mixture.
Step 14: Store the ladoos in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

recipes.name: Murmura Ladoo (Puffed Rice Balls)
ingredients: ½ teaspoon cardamom powder or 2-3 green cardamom pods, crushed
directions: Step 1: Prepare Ingredients: Grate or powder the jaggery and crush the cardamom pods if using whole spices. Set aside.
Step 2: Dry Roast Puffed Rice: In a pan over medium heat, dry roast the puffed rice (murmura) for 1-2 minutes until crisp. Transfer to a bowl and set aside.
Step 3: Make Jaggery Syrup: In a separate pan, combine the grated jaggery and water. Heat over low flame, stirring constantly, until the jaggery melts and forms a smooth syrup.
Step 4: Strain Jaggery Syrup (Optional): For a smoother texture, strain the melted jaggery through a sieve to remove any impurities. Transfer the strained syrup back to the pan.
Step 5: Thicken Syrup: Heat the strained jaggery syrup over low flame, stirring continuously. Add cardamom powder (if using).

Step 6: Check Syrup Consistency: To check the consistency, drop a few drops of syrup into a bowl of cold water. The drops should form soft, pliable balls that hold their shape. Alternatively, the syrup should form a string when dropped from a spoon.
Step 7: Combine Puffed Rice and Syrup: Pour the prepared jaggery syrup over the roasted puffed rice. Mix well to coat the puffed rice evenly.
Step 8: Add Roasted Gram: Add the roasted gram to the mixture and mix thoroughly.
Step 9: Shape Ladoos: Lightly grease your palms with water or ghee. While the mixture is still warm, take small portions and shape them into round balls (ladoos) by pressing gently.
Step 10: Cool and Serve: Allow the ladoos to cool completely before serving. Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

recipes.name: Motichoor Ladoo
ingredients: A generous pinch saffron powder or crushed saffron threads
Oil or ghee for greasing palms
directions: Step 1: In a pan, combine the sugar, saffron, and ½ cup of water. Heat over medium heat until the sugar dissolves completely.

Step 2: Continue cooking the sugar syrup until it reaches a one-thread consistency. To test this, drop a small amount of syrup into a bowl of cold water; it should form a single, short thread. Remove from heat and set aside.

Step 3: In a separate bowl, whisk together the besan, saffron, and ½ cup of water until a smooth, lump-free batter forms. The batter should be pourable but not too thin. Adjust the water quantity as needed depending on the besan quality.
Step 4: Heat oil in a deep frying pan or kadai over medium heat. The oil should be hot but not smoking.

Step 5: Hold a perforated ladle over the hot oil. Pour a spoonful of batter onto the ladle and press gently with another spoon, so the batter falls through the holes and into the oil in small droplets.
Step 6: Fry the boondis (small droplets) until golden, about 45-60 seconds. Avoid over-frying, as they should remain soft. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Step 7: Immediately transfer the fried boondis to the warm sugar syrup. Stir gently to coat them evenly.
Step 8: If the sugar syrup cools down or crystallizes, reheat gently with 1-2 tablespoons of water.
Step 9: Repeat steps 5-7 until all the batter is used.
Step 10: Once all boondis are in the syrup, transfer the mixture to a blender. Add 1 tablespoon of hot water and pulse a few times to break down the boondis slightly. Do not over-process.
Step 11: If the mixture appears too dry, add another 1-2 tablespoons of hot water. The boondis should be soft and moist.
Step 12: Add the melon seeds and black cardamom seeds to the boondi mixture. Mix well.
Step 13: Lightly grease your palms with oil or ghee. Shape the warm boondi mixture into small, round ladoos. They will firm up as they cool.
Step 14: Garnish with extra melon seeds or raisins, if desired.
